ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Requests adjusted p-values by using the Hochberg and Benjamini (1990) adaptive step-up 
Bonferroni method.

Requests adjusted p-values by using the Hochberg and Benjamini (1990) adaptive step-down 
Bonferroni method.

Requests adjusted p-values by using the Benjamini and Hochberg (2000) adaptive linear 
step-up method.
Specifies that the Bonferroni adjustments (number of tests x p-value) be computed for each test.

Specifies that the p-values be adjusted by using the bootstrap method to resample vectors (Westfall 
and Young; 1993).

Requests that continuous variables be mean-centered prior to resampling. The default action is to 
mean-center for bootstrap resampling and not to mean-center for permutation resampling.

[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the input SAS data set to be used by PROC MULTTEST.
Requests adjusted p-values by using the method of Benjamini and Yekateuli (2001).

[Syntax: EPSILON=number] 
      
Specifies the amount by which two p-values must differ to be declared unequal. 
The value number must be between 0 and 1; the default value is 1000 times the 
machine epsilon, which is approximately 1E–12.
Requests adjusted p-values by using the linear step-up method of Benjamini and Hochberg (1995).

[Syntax: FDRBOOT<(β)>] 
      
A bootstrap-resampling false discovery rate controlling method due to Yekateuli 
and Benjamini (1999).

[Syntax: FDERPERM<(β)>] 
      
A permutation-resampling false discovery rate controlling method due to Yekateuli 
and Benjamini (1999).
Requests adjusted p-values by using Fisher’s combination method.
Requests adjusted p-values by using the step-up Bonferroni method due to Hochberg (1988).
Requests adjusted p-values by using the method of Hommel (1988).
Is an alias for the STEPBON adjustment

[Syntax: INPVALUES<(pvalue-name)>=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names an input SAS data set that includes a variable containing raw p-values. 
The pvalue-name enables you to specify the name of the p-value column from 
your data set. By default, pvalue-name=’raw_p’.

Requests that continuous variables not be mean-centered prior to resampling. The default action is to 
mean-center for bootstrap resampling and not to mean-center for permutation resampling.
Suppresses the normal display of results.

Suppresses the display of the "p-Values" table of raw and adjusted p-values. This option is most useful
when you are adjusting many tests and need to create only an OUT= data set or display graphics.
Suppresses display of the "Discrete Variable Tabulations" and "Continuous Variable Tabulations" tables.
Suppresses display of tables having zero occurrences for all CLASS levels.

[Syntax: NSAMPLE=number] 
      
Specifies the number of resamples for use with the resampling methods. The value 
number must be a positive integer; by default, 20,000 resamples are used.

[Syntax: NTRUENULL=keyword | value] 
      
Controls the method used to estimate the number of true NULL hypotheses (mo) for 
the adaptive methods.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Syntax: BOOTSTRAP<(bootstrap-options)>           Uses the bootstrap method of Storey and Tibshirani (2003). The available bootstrap-options  are as follows:                                   FINITE    modifies the computations for the finite-sample case of the PFDR option.     NBOOT=B    specifies the number of bootstrap resamples of the raw p-values for the λ computations.     NLAMBDA=n    specifies that the "optimal" λ is the value in {0, 1/n,...,(n-1)/n} that minimizes the MSE.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Uses the method of Schweder and Spjøtvoll (1982) as modified by Hochberg and Benjamini (1990).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Syntax: KSTEST<(β)<                                  Uses the Kolmogov-Smirnov uniformity test method of Turkheimer, Smith, and Schmidt (2001).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Uses a linear least squares method to search for the correct cutpoint.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Uses the lowest slope method of Benjamini and Hochberg (2000).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Uses the mean of differences method of Hsueh, Chen, and Kodell (2003).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Syntax: SPLINE<(spline-options)>                                  Uses the cubic spline method of Storey and Tibshirani (2003).  The available spline-options are as follows:     DF=df    sets the degrees of freedom of the spline, where df is a nonnegative integer. The default is DF=3.     DFCONV=number    specifies the absolute change in spline degrees of freedom value for concluding convergence.     FINITE    modifies the computations for the finite-sample case of the PFDR option.     MAXITER=n    specifies the maximum number of golden-search iterations used to find a spline with DF= degrees of freedom.     NLAMBDA=n    By default, NLAMBDA=20; number must be an integer greater than 1.     SPCONV=number    specifies the absolute change in smoothing parameter value for concluding convergence of the spline.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the sorting order for the levels of the CLASS variable.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Orders values according to their order in the input data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order  depends on your operating environment.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output SAS data set containing variable names, contrast names, intermediate 
calculations, and all associated p-values.

[Syntax: OUTPERM=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output SAS data set containing entire permutation distributions (upper-tail 
probabilities) for all tests when the PERMUTATION= option is specified.

[Syntax: OUTSAMP=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output SAS data set containing information from the resampled data 
sets when resampling is performed.

[Syntax: PDATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Is an alias for the INPVALUES= option.

Computes adjusted p-values in identical fashion as the BOOTSTRAP option, with the exception that 
PROC MULTTEST resamples without replacement rather than with replacement.

[Syntax: PFDR<(options )>] 
      
Computes the "q-values". PROC MULTTEST treats these "q-values" as adjusted p-values.

Controls the plots produced through ODS Graphics. 
      
Syntax: 
(1) PLOTS<(global-plot-options)>=plot-request<(options)> 
(2) PLOTS<(global-plot-options)>=(plot-request<(options)>< plot-request<(options)>> ) 

The following global-plot-options are available: 

  UNPACKPANELS | UNPACK 
  suppresses paneling.

  SIGONLY<=number> 
  displays only those tests with adjusted p-values ≤ number, where 0 ≤ number ≤ 1.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Syntax: ADJUSTED<(UNPACK)>           Displays a 22 panel of adjusted p-value plots similar to those Storey and Tibshirani (2003) developed  for use with the PFDR p-value adjustment method. The UNPACK option unpanels the display.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Displays plots of the MSE and the estimated number of true nulls against the λ parameter when the  NTRUENULL=SPLINE or NTRUENULL=BOOTSTRAP option is in effect.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Syntax: MANHATTAN<(options)>                                  Displays the Manhattan plot (a plot of -log10 of the adjusted p-values versus the tests). You can  specify the following options:   GROUP=variable     specifies a variable to group the adjusted p-values in the display.   LABEL <=OBS>     labels the observations that have adjusted p-values that are less than the value specified in     the VREF= option. By default, labels are created as follows: if an INPVALUES= data set     and an ID statement are specified, then the observations are labeled with the ID values; if a     DATA= data set is specified, then the observations are labeled with their constructed test     name; otherwise, the observation or test number is displayed.   NOTESTNAME     displays the number of the test instead of the test name on the X-axis, which is useful when     you have many tests.   UNPACK     suppresses paneling. By default, Manhattan plots are created for each requested p-value     adjustment, and the results are grouped in a single display, called a panel. Specify UNPACK     to display each plot separately.   VREF=number | NONE     displays a reference line at –log10(number). The number must be between 0 and 1. By     default, a reference line at –log10(0.05) is displayed; it can be suppressed by specifying     VREF=0 or VREF=NONE.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Syntax: PBYTEST<(options)>                                  Displays the adjusted p-values for each test. The available options are as follows:     NOTESTNAME    displays the number of the test instead of the test name on the axis, which is useful when    you have many tests.     VREF=number-list    displays reference lines at the p-values specified in the number-list. The values in the    number-list must be between 0 and 1;
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Syntax: RAWPROB<(UNPACK)>                                  Displays a uniform probability plot of 1 minus the raw p-values (Schweder and Spjøtvoll; 1982)  along with a histogram. The UNPACK option unpanels the display.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PTRUENULL=keyword | value] 
      
Is alias for the NTRUENULL= option, except that you can specify the proportion 
of true null hypotheses as a value between 0 and 1, instead of specifying the number 
of true null hypotheses. The available keywords are also the NTRUENULL= options.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Syntax: BOOTSTRAP<(bootstrap-options)>           Uses the bootstrap method of Storey and Tibshirani (2003). The available bootstrap-options  are as follows:                                   FINITE    modifies the computations for the finite-sample case of the PFDR option.     NBOOT=B    specifies the number of bootstrap resamples of the raw p-values for the λ computations.     NLAMBDA=n    specifies that the "optimal" λ is the value in {0, 1/n,...,(n-1)/n} that minimizes the MSE.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Uses the method of Schweder and Spjøtvoll (1982) as modified by Hochberg and Benjamini (1990).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Syntax: KSTEST<(β)<                                  Uses the Kolmogov-Smirnov uniformity test method of Turkheimer, Smith, and Schmidt (2001).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Uses a linear least squares method to search for the correct cutpoint.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Uses the lowest slope method of Benjamini and Hochberg (2000).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Uses the mean of differences method of Hsueh, Chen, and Kodell (2003).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Syntax: SPLINE<(spline-options)>                                  Uses the cubic spline method of Storey and Tibshirani (2003).  The available spline-options are as follows:     DF=df    sets the degrees of freedom of the spline, where df is a nonnegative integer. The default is DF=3.     DFCONV=number    specifies the absolute change in spline degrees of freedom value for concluding convergence.     FINITE    modifies the computations for the finite-sample case of the PFDR option.     MAXITER=n    specifies the maximum number of golden-search iterations used to find a spline with DF= degrees of freedom.     NLAMBDA=n    By default, NLAMBDA=20; number must be an integer greater than 1.     SPCONV=number    specifies the absolute change in smoothing parameter value for concluding convergence of the spline.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Requests the random number generator used in releases prior to SAS 9.2.

[Syntax: SEED=number] 
      
Specifies the initial seed for the random number generator used for resampling. The 
value for number must be an integer.
Computes the Šidák adjustment for each test.
Requests adjusted p-values by using the step-down Bonferroni method of Holm (1979).

Requests that adjusted p-values be computed by using bootstrap resampling as described under the 
BOOTSTRAP option, but in step-down fashion.

Requests that adjusted p-values be computed by using permutation resampling as described under the 
PERMUTATION option, but in step-down fashion.

Requests adjusted p-values by using the Šidák method as described in the SIDAK option, but in 
step-down fashion.

Requests adjusted p-values by using the Stouffer-Liptak combination method.
      
This option is new under SAS 9.3.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately 
follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: FREQ variable;
      
The FREQ statement names a variable that provides frequencies for each observation in the DATA= 
data set. Specifically, if n is the value of the FREQ variable for a given observation, then that 
observation is used n times.

Syntax: ID variables;
      
The ID statement names one or more variables for identifying observations in the output and in the plots. 
The statement requires an INPVALUES= data set. All ID variables are displayed in the “pValues” table. The 
ID variables are used as the X axis for the plots requested by the PLOTS=PBYTEST and PLOTS=MANHATTAN
options in the PROC MULTTEST statement; they are also used to label points on the Manhattan plots. This
option has no effect on the OUT= data set.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that class levels should be determined by using no more than the first 16 characters of 
the formatted values of CLASS variables.
Specifies the type of strata weighting to use when computing the Freeman-Tukey and t tests.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Requests weights proportional to the within-stratum sample sizes, and is the default method.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sets up weights equal to the harmonic mean of the nonmissing within-stratum CLASS sizes, and is similar to a Type 2 analysis in PROC GLM.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies equal weights, and is similar to a Type 3 analysis in PROC GLM.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Requests the Cochran-Armitage linear trend tests for group comparisons. The test variables should 
take the value 0 for a failure and 1 for a success. PERMUTATION= option can be used to request 
an exact permutation test; otherwise, a Z-score approximation is used. The CONTINUITY= option 
can be used to specify a continuity correction for the -score approximation.

Requests Fisher exact tests for comparing two treatment groups. The test variables should take the 
value 0 for a failure and 1 for a success.

Requests Z-score CA tests based upon the Freeman-Tukey double arcsine transformation of the 
frequencies. The test variables should take the value 0 for a failure and 1 for a success.
Requests the t test for the mean. The test variables can take on any numeric values.

Requests the Peto mortality-prevalence test. The test variables should take the value 0 for a 
nonoccurrence, 1 for an incidental occurrence, and 2 for a fatal occurrence. The TIME= option 
should be used with the Peto test to specify an integer-valued variable giving the age at death. 
The CONTINUITY= option can be used to specify a continuity correction for the test.

Uses the binomial variance estimate for CA and Peto tests in their asymptotic normal approximations. 
The default is to use the hypergeometric variance.

[Syntax: CONTINUITY=number] 
          
Specifies number as a particular continuity correction for the Z-score approximation 
in the CA and Peto tests. The default is 0.
Is used to make all tests lower-tailed. All tests are two-tailed by default.

[Syntax: PERMUTATION=number] 
          
Computes p-values for the CA and Peto tests by using exact permutation distributions 
when marginal success or failure totals within a stratum are number or less.

Specifies whether the MEAN test uses a homogeneity assumption (DDFM=POOLED, the default) or deals with 
heterogeneous variances (DDFM=SATTERTHWAITE).

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the MEAN test uses a homogeneity assumption.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the MEAN test deals with heterogeneous variances.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: TIME=variable] 
          
Identifies the Peto test variable containing the age at death, which must be 
integer valued. If the TIME= option is omitted, all ages are assumed to equal 1.
Is used to make all tests upper-tailed. All tests are two-tailed by default.
